qas.question: When were the mediatisation changes confirmed?
Which kingdom acquired some Thuringian territory?
Who led the unification of Germany in 1871?
Which city became the capital of Thuringia after World War 1?
When was the German Mediatisation unknown?
When were the Mediatisation changes denied?
Which kingdom lost some Thuringian territory?
Who stopped the unification of Germany in 1871?
Which city became the capital of Thuringia after World War 3?

context: Some reordering of the Thuringian states occurred during the German Mediatisation from <a0_0><b5_0>1795 to 1814<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and the territory was included within the Napoleonic Confederation of the Rhine organized in 1806. <a1_0><b6_0>The 1815 Congress of Vienna<b6_0/><a1_0/> confirmed these changes and the Thuringian states' inclusion in the German Confederation; <a2_0><b7_0>the Kingdom of Prussia<b7_0/><a2_0/> also acquired some Thuringian territory and administered it within the Province of Saxony. The Thuringian duchies which became part of the German Empire in 1871 during the <a3_0><b8_0>Prussian-led<b8_0/><a3_0/> unification of Germany were Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, Saxe-Meiningen, Saxe-Altenburg, Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, Schwarzburg-Sondershausen, Schwarzburg-Rudolstadt and the two principalities of Reuss Elder Line and Reuss Younger Line. In 1920, after World War I, these small states merged into one state, called Thuringia; only Saxe-Coburg voted to join Bavaria instead. <a4_0><b9_0>Weimar<b9_0/><a4_0/> became the new capital of Thuringia. The coat of arms of this new state was simpler than they had been previously.
